system
Class SpaceImpl

java.lang.Object
  java.rmi.server.RemoteObject
      java.rmi.server.RemoteServer
          java.rmi.server.UnicastRemoteObject
              system.SpaceImpl
All Implemented Interfaces:
Client2Space, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Runnable, java.rmi.Remote, Computer2Space
public class SpaceImpl
extends java.rmi.server.UnicastRemoteObject
implements Client2Space, Computer2Space, java.lang.Runnable

Implementation of the Space Interface. Represents a raw computing resource where tasks (Task) are automatically executed by registered workers as soon as they are dropped in. If a worker crashes, the computation would still continue (assuming there are other workers still running), since each task is executed under a transaction, which would be rolled back after the worker crashed, leaving the task in the space for another worker to pick up. For more information, please refer How to build a compute farm. The multithreading design implemented by this class is that of the Cilk runtime. Please read the architecture of Cilk to understand the class better.

Author:
Manasa Chandrasekhar, Kowshik Prakasam
See Also:

compute

public Result<?> compute(Task<?> aTask,
                         Shared<?> shared)
                  throws java.rmi.RemoteException
Description copied from interface: Client2Space
The client passes a Task object representing a complex computation to the Space via this method. In principle, these Task objects are processed in parallel by workers by the Space. This method blocks until a Result object containing the result of the task is available to be returned to the client.

Specified by:
compute in interface Client2Space
Parameters:
aTask - task to be added to the Compute Space
shared - Shared object to be used to broadcast messages across workers in the compute space for this task
Returns:
One of the results obtained upon completion of individual tasks
Throws:
java.rmi.RemoteException - Thrown if any read/write errors occur during the process of adding a task to the queue in the compute space or if any errors occur during resource allocation in the compute space
See Also:
Client2Space.compute(Task, Shared)
